What Are React Components?

React components are the building blocks of a React application.
Each component represents a small, independent, and reusable part of the user interface — like buttons, forms, menus, or entire pages.

You can think of them like LEGO pieces:
each one is self-contained, but together they create a full, interactive application.

🧠 Main Ideas

Reusability – A component can be used in many places without rewriting it.
Example: one "Button" component might appear on several screens.

Modularity – The app is split into small, manageable pieces instead of one big file.
This makes it easier to maintain and understand.

Composition – Components can contain other components.
For instance, a "Page" component might include a "Header", "Sidebar", and "Footer".

Data Flow – Data usually flows from parent to child through something called props (short for properties).
This allows customization of each component's behavior and appearance.

State Management – Components can have their own state, meaning they can remember information, react to user actions, and update the screen automatically.

Declarative Nature – Instead of manually changing the page, you describe what the UI should look like at any moment, and React updates it for you.

Lifecycle – Each component has a "life cycle": it is created, updated when data changes, and removed when no longer needed.

💡 Why Components Are Powerful

They make development faster and cleaner.

They encourage consistent design and logic.

They simplify debugging and testing.

They enable teamwork — different developers can work on different components.
